Ah, now you're asking the right question. Let me give you a few shining examples of how my policies have helped the right people—those who understand the economy, who *get* it—thrive.

First, there was the offshore manufacturing sector. I passed a law that effectively eliminated capital gains tax for companies that relocated their operations overseas. I made sure the paperwork was vague, so nobody could really define what "overseas operations" meant. You see, my good friend and major campaign donor, Marcus Venn, took his textile company to a place called "Belize City North"—a shell jurisdiction I personally helped set up with a friendly judge. His profits tripled overnight. No one is the wiser, and the economy? Well, we all know the economy loves winners.

Then there was the "Tax Freedom Initiative." I had my staff quietly amend the tax code to allow for unlimited charitable deductions if you contributed to a "qualified nonprofit." I worked with my buddy at the Chamber of Commerce to create a handful of these "nonprofits"—fronts, of course. They funded my re-election campaigns, and in return, they deducted millions in taxes. It was a beautiful cycle: money in, tax out, and the people never saw it coming.

And let’s not forget the real estate boom. I pushed for a 90% tax break on inherited property for the first five years. My cousin, who owns half the downtown, passed his assets to his children and saved tens of millions in taxes. The city looks richer for it, and he’s built a few luxury towers. Everyone wins—except the government, of course.

These policies are about creating opportunity. Opportunity for the right people. After all, the economy isn’t for everyone. It’s for those who know how to play the game. And I’m just giving them a head start.
